newsitem.title: UK: Black British MP apologises for nursing race row.
newsitem.headline: Black British MP apologises for nursing race row.

text.p: A British member of parliament apologised on Thursday for criticising the hospital in her constituency for hiring "blonde, blue-eyed Finnish nurses."
Diane Abbott, a prominent black member of the opposition Labour party, said she was sorry and upset about the comment, interpreted as a racial slur, and the row that ensued.
"I very much regret that one sentence of my article for a local paper has led to a widespread misunderstanding of my position," she said in a statement.
"As a local MP I was emphasising the importance of recruiting locally. I am sorry and upset that what I said has been interpreted as a racist statement."

In a column in her local paper the left-wing MP said she was surprised that a hospital in her district hired from Finland, instead of recruiting Caribbean nurses who know the language and understood British culture and institutions.

"Are Finnish girls, who may never have met a black person before, let alone touched one, best suited to nurse in multicultural Hackney?" she asked in her column. "Black nurses are leaving the profession all the time because of racism."
The comments caused an uproar and several letters of complaint, including one from hospital officials detailing the staff shortages they faced.
Newspapers also criticised Abbott's "hysterical tirade" and described her as "an extrovert with a huge chip on her shoulder."

"Imagine Diane Abbott's view reversed as in a photographic negative. It is difficult to exaggerate the offence such words would have provoked had they been expressed by a white woman in regard to black nurses," the Daily Mail said in an editorial.
A senior nurse at the London hospital said 30 nurses from Finland, where there is a surplus of nurses, had been hired to plug the gap and another 20 were due in 1997.
Staff nurse Satu Jaaskelainen, 25, said she was insulted by Abbott's comments. "It has made me very, very, angry. I treat all my patients the same," she told The Daily Telegraph.
Another nurse called Abbott's remarks ridiculous and said the most important thing was that nurses were competent.
